Question Body: Let's assume that an organization needs to process large amounts of data in bursts, on a cloud-based Kubernetes cluster. A. Run a group of nodes with the exact required size to complete the batch on time, and use a combination of taints, tolerations, and nodeSelectors to reserve these nodes to the batch jobs.

C. Commit to a specific level of spending to get discounted prices (with e.g. “reserved instances” or similar mechanisms).

Question Body: SUMULATION - Which file in the /proc filesystem lists parameters passed from the bootloader to the kernel? (Specify the file name only without any path.)
Question Choices: VERIFY - No multiple choice answers found. Perhaps an image?

Question Body: Which of the following are init systems used within Linux systems? (Choose THREE correct answers.)
Question Choices:
A. startd
B. systemd
C. Upstart
D. SysInit
E. SysV init

Question Body: Which of the following commands reboots the system when using SysV init? (Choose TWO correct answers.)
Question Choices:
A. shutdown -r now
B. shutdown -r "rebooting"
C. telinit 6
D. telinit 0
E. shutdown -k now "rebooting"

Question Body: Which of the following information is stored within the BIOS? (Choose TWO correct answers.)
Question Choices:
A. Boot device order
B. Linux kernel version
C. Timezone
D. Hardware configuration
E. The system's hostname

Question Body: What of the following statements are true regarding /dev/ when using udev? (Choose TWO correct answers.)
Question Choices:
A. Entries for all possible devices get created on boot even if those devices are not connected.
B. Additional rules for udev can be created by adding them to /etc/udev/rules.d/.
C. When using udev, it is not possible to create block or character devices in /dev/ using mknod.
D. The /dev/ directory is a filesystem of type tmpfs and is mounted by udev during system startup.
E. The content of /dev/ is stored in /etc/udev/dev and is restored during system startup.

Question Body: Which of the following statements is correct when talking about /proc/?
Question Choices:
A. All changes to files in /proc/ are stored in /etc/proc.d/ and restored on reboot.
B. All files within /proc/ are read-only and their contents cannot be changed.
C. All changes to files in /proc/ are immediately recognized by the kernel.
D. All files within /proc/ are only readable by the root user.

Question Body: Which run levels should never be declared as the default run level when using SysV init? (Choose TWO correct answers.)
Which SysV init configuration file should be modified to disable the ctrl-alt-delete key combination?
Question Choices:
A. /etc/keys
B. /proc/keys
C. /etc/inittab
D. /proc/inittab
E. /etc/reboot

Question Body: During a system boot cycle, what program is executed after the BIOS completes its tasks?
Question Choices:
A. The bootloader
B. The inetd program
C. The init program
D. The kernel

Question Body: Which of the following commands can be used to display the inode number of a given file?
Question Choices:
A. inode
B. ls
C. ln
D. cp

Question Body: Which of the following commands will NOT update the modify timestamp on the file /tmp/myfile.txt?
Question Choices:
A. file /tmp/myfile.txt
B. echo "Hello" >/tmp/myfile.txt
C. sed -ie "s/1/2/" /tmp/myfile.txt
D. echo -n "Hello" >>/tmp/myfile.txt
E. touch /tmp/myfile.txt

Question Body: SIMULATION - Which umask value will result in the default access permissions of 600 (rw-------) for files and 700 (rwx------) for directories? (Specify only the numerical umask value.)
Question Choices: VERIFY - No multiple choice answers found. Perhaps an image?

Question Body: What is the effect of the egrep command when the -v option is used?
Question Choices:
A. It enables color to highlight matching parts.
B. It only outputs non-matching lines.
C. It shows the command's version information.
D. It changes the output order showing the last matching line first.

Question Body: What is the difference between the commands test -e path and test -f path?
Question Choices:
A. They are equivalent options with the same behavior.
B. The -f option tests for a regular file.  The -e option tests for an empty file.
C. Both options check the existence of the path.  The -f option also confirms that it is a regular file.
D. The -f option tests for a regular file.  The -e option tests for an executable file.
